# The `Type` Class Reference

<DoxygenPage pluginConfig={pluginConfig}>

Just like <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/type">llvm::Type</a> these are immutable, unique, never get freed and can only be created via static factory methods. <a href="#details">More...</a>

## Declaration

<CodeBlock>class llvm::sandboxir::Type</CodeBlock>

## Description {#details}

Just like <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/type">llvm::Type</a> these are immutable, unique, never get freed and can only be created via static factory methods.

Definition at line 43 of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/sandboxir/type-h">Type.h</a>.

This is only valid on floating-point types. If the FP type does not have a stable mantissa (e.g. ppc long double), this method returns -1.

### getPrimitiveSizeInBits() {#a595135fd17d77e8ed5e48a8033e5fa24}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype="TypeSize llvm::sandboxir::Type::getPrimitiveSizeInBits () const"
  labels = {["inline"]}>
Return the basic size of this type if it is a primitive type.

These are fixed by LLVM and are not target-dependent. This will return zero if the type does not have a size or is not a primitive type.

If this is a scalable vector type, the scalable property will be set and the runtime size will be a positive integer multiple of the base size.

Note that this may not reflect the size of memory allocated for an instance of the type or the number of bytes that are written when an instance of the type is stored to memory. The <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/datalayout">DataLayout</a> class provides additional query functions to provide this information.

Definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/sandboxir/type-h/#l00247">247</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/sandboxir/type-h">Type.h</a>.
</MemberDefinition>

### isFPOrFPVectorTy() {#a609b0218dcee7182f7da35c0269a089e}

Returns true if this is a floating-point type that is an unevaluated sum of multiple floating-point units.

An example of such a type is ppc&#95;fp128, also known as double-double, which consists of two IEEE 754 doubles.

### print() {#a5c4661418be55867a719a892bcec6171}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>void llvm::sandboxir::Type::print (<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/raw-ostream">raw&#95;ostream</a> &amp; OS, bool IsForDebug=false, bool NoDetails=false) const</>}
  labels = {["inline"]}>
Print the current type.

Omit the type details if <code>NoDetails</code> == true. E.g., let st = type &#123; i32, i16 &#125; When <code>NoDetails</code> is true, we only print st. Put differently, <code>NoDetails</code> prints the type as if inlined with the operands when printing an instruction.

Definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/sandboxir/type-h/#l00084">84</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/sandboxir/type-h">Type.h</a>.
</MemberDefinition>
